questions.question: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with craniotabes, rachitic rosary and bowed legs.Diagnosis of rickets was made. To investigate the cause of rickets and to find the status ofvitamin D in the body, which of the following should be measured?
questions.explanation: Measurement of 25 hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) provides more accurate information aboutvitamin D levels.PTH is increased in vitamin D deficiency. PTH is a major stimulus for the 1° -hydroxylase, so thereis increased synthesis of the active hormone, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. Paradoxically, levels of thishormone are often normal in severe vitamin D deficiency. Therefore, measurements of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D are not accurate reflections of vitamin D stores and should not be used todiagnose vitamin D deficiency in patients with normal renal function.

questions.question: Which of the following decreases the conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25dihydroxycholecalciferol?
questions.explanation: The conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is done by enzyme1° -hydroxylase which is present in the kidney. In chronic renal failure (CRF), there is a deficiencyof this enzyme and formation of the active form of vitamin D does not take place.Factors which increase activity of 1° -hydroxylase are:•Ca2+ deficiency•• Increased parathyroid hormone (PTH)

questions.question: In an experiment, a rat is infused with a small volume of a calcium chloride solution.Compared to the control condition, which of the following would result from the calciumload?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, increased formation of 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol will take place.Infusion of calcium chloride solution will lead to raised calcium concentration in blood. At highercalcium concentrations, PTH is also suppressed. So the 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to adifferent compound: 24,25dihydroxycholecalciferol that has almost no vitamin D effect.When plasma calcium concentration is high, formation of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol is alsogreatly depressed. Lack of 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, in turn, decreases the absorption ofcalcium from the intestines, bones, and renal tubules, thus causing the calcium ion concentrationto fall back toward its normal level.Option A: Since PTH levels are supressed bone demineralisation does not take place.Option B: Calcitonin is a calcium regulatory hormone whose level increases when the calciumconcentration in plasma is high.Option C: Calcium ions are a part of the coagulation cascade and the blood coaguability eitherincreases or remains the same with high plasma Ca+2 levels.

questions.question: Calcium absorption takes place mainly from which of the following sites?
questions.explanation: Calcium absorption is mainly from the proximal small intestine (duodenum).Vit D and PTH are important factors that control calcium absorption.

questions.question: Which of the following is an enhancer of calcium absorption from the intestine?
questions.explanation: Ca 2+ absorption is enhanced by proteins.It is inhibited by phosphates, phytic acid, and oxalates because these anions form insoluble saltswith Ca 2+ in the intestine.

questions.question: Which of the following is the active form of calcium?
questions.explanation: Ionic calcium is the active form that is important for most functions of calcium in the body,including the effect of calcium on the heart, the nervous system, and bone formation.Most of the calcium (99%) is stored in the bones. Only about 0.1 percent of the total body calcium•is in the extracellular fluid and 1 percent is in the cells and its organelles.From the 0.1% Ca+2 in the plasma, the distribution of calcium is as follows:• About 41 % is combined with the plasma proteins (non-diffusible through the capillarymembrane)756•• About 9 % is combined with anionic substances of the plasma and interstitial fluids like citrateand phosphate in such a manner that it is not ionized (diffusible through the capillary membrane);and• The remaining 50 % of the calcium in the plasma is both diffusible through the capillarymembrane and ionized.

questions.question: On infusing parathyroid hormone in experimental mice, there is increased resorption of bonedue to stimulation of the osteoclastic activity. Which of the following is true regarding thecellular mechanism of osteoclastic activation?

options.A: The bone-resorbing osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors
options.B: Osteoclasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG) a cytokine that increases bone resorption
options.C: RANK ligand and M-CSF are necessary for formation of mature osteoblasts
options.D: Glucocorticoids promote osteoblast activity and inhibit bone resorption

questions.explanation: Osteoclast cells do not have PTH receptors. PTH stimulates osteoclast activity and boneresorption by an indirect mechanism.757PTH has receptors on the osteoblasts in the bone. When PTH binds to these receptors, osteoblastsrelease cytokines like RANK-ligand and M-CSF. These cytokines allow the differentiation ofmacrophages to osteoclasts.Osteoclasts, in turn, cut the collagen in the bone, which is bound to calcium. This causes therelease of calcium, phosphorus, and collagen breakdown products in the blood.Osteoblasts produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), or osteoclastogenesis inhibitory factor, a cytokinethat inhibits bone resorption by preventing interaction of RANKL with its receptor. PTHdecreases the production of osteoprotegerin (OPG).Glucocorticoids promote osteoclast activity and increase bone resorption by increasing RANKLproduction and decreasing the formation of OPG. On the other hand, the hormone estrogenstimulates OPG production.

questions.question: A mouse is engineered to lack a transcription factor necessary for the normal development ofosteoclasts. Compared to normal littermate mice, which of the following would be reduced inthe knocked-out mouse?
questions.explanation: Secretion of acid proteases would be decreased in the knocked-out mouse. Osteoclasts produceproteolytic enzymes and several acids necessary for bone resorption. The enzymes digest ordissolve the organic matrix of the bone, and the acids cause dissolution of the bone salts.A knocked-out mouse is a genetically modified mouse in which an existing gene is inactivated or'knocked out' by replacing it with an artificial one. The control mice used in the above case arelittermate mice i.e mice with genetically modified embryonic stem (ES) cell strains used to testwhether specific genes control a disease or immunological phenomena (eg: normal osteoclasticdevelopment)Option B: The acidic pH caused by the osteoclasts dissolves hydroxyapatite. In the knocked-outmouse, hydroxyapatite levels would therefore increase.Option A and C: Since the lineage of osteoclasts and osteoblasts is different, there is no decreasein the proliferation of osteoblasts. As the osteoblast levels are normal, phosphate deposition inbone also remains normal.

questions.question: 748Which of the following is true regarding calcium homeostasis?

options.A: 90% of calcium is filtered from the glomerulus
options.B: Calcium is reabsorbed mainly from the late distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
options.C: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) promotes calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules
options.D: Calcitonin promotes action of parathyroid hormone

questions.explanation: PTH promotes the reabsorption of calcium from the renal tubules.Option A: About 41 percent of the plasma calcium is bound to plasma proteins and is thereforenot filtered by the glomerular capillaries. The rest of the calcium is filtered through the glomeruliinto the renal tubules.Option B: Of the filtered calcium, approximately 90 percent is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules,loops of Henle, and early distal tubules. However, when calcium levels are low and PTH levelsrise, PTH promotes calcium reabsorption from the later DCT.Option D: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration and, in general, has effectsopposite to those of PTH.758

questions.question: Which of the following is not an effect of parathormone?
questions.explanation: PTH does not increase phosphate reabsorption in kidney, rather it causes decreased phosphatereabsorption in the kidney.

questions.question: A 30-year-old lady undergoes thyroidectomy due to suspected malignancy. A week after thesurgery she develops a spasm of facial muscles on tapping over the facial nerve in front of thetragus. Which of the following is the reason behind her muscle hyperexcitability?
questions.explanation: activityCalcitonin+Plasma (Ca2+) and PKidneyInhibits Ca2+ and P₁reabsorption761The given clinical vignette is suggestive of chvostek sign, seen in hypocalcemia due to accidentalparathyroid injury during thyroid surgery. The muscle hyperexcitability seen in hypocalcemia isdue to increased permeability of cells to Na+.During thyroid surgery, parathyroid gland is prone to accidental injury due to proximity with thethyroid gland. Damage to the parathyroid gland will lead to a low PTH level and low Ca2+ level.When the ECF concentration of Ca2+ falls below normal, the nervous system becomesprogressively more excitable. Because there is increased membrane permeability to Na+. Thisleads to easy initiation of the action potentials.The peripheral nerve fibres become so excitable that they begin to discharge spontaneously,initiating impulses that pass to the skeletal muscles to elicit tetanic muscle contraction. Tetanyoccurs usually when calcium concentration falls to 6 mg/dL.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding confounders affecting serum calcium level?

options.A: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentration.
options.B: Forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized calcium levels
options.C: Hemoconcentration due to tourniquet results in a rise of serum calcium
options.D: Acidosis causes a decrease in the ionized calcium levels

questions.explanation: Acidosis does not cause a decrease in the ionized calcium levels. Rather, alkalosis causes adecrease in the ionized calcium levels.Plasma proteins are more ionized when the pH is high (alkalosis), providing more protein anionsto bind with and sequester free Ca2+. This causes a decrease in ionized calcium and may triggersymptoms of hypocalcemia.Option A: Total calcium concentration is altered by variations in the serum albumin concentrationas 41% of calcium is bound to plasma proteins like albumin, hence changes in albuminconcentration affects the serum calcium levels. The corrected calcium levels can be calculated as:Corrected calcium (mg/dL) = measured total Ca (mg/dL) + 0.8 (4.0 - serum albumin [g/dL]), where4.0 represents the average albumin level.Option B: Fist-clenching or forearm exercise can lead to falsely elevated ionized (free) calciumlevels.Option C: A tourniquet is usually avoided while drawing blood for calcium measurements sincehemoconcentration also leads to an increase in serum calcium levels.

questions.question: Which of the following cells is involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity?
questions.explanation: Osteoblasts are involved in the initiation and control of osteoclastic activity.Osteoblasts produce receptor activator for nuclear factor кB ligand (RANKL) and macrophagecolony stimulating factor (M-CSF), which are necessary for formation of mature osteoclasts andhence osteoclastic activity.Specific receptors for parathormone are present only on the osteoblasts and not on osteoclasts.

questions.question: Which of these is not a marker of bone resorption?
questions.explanation: 762Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase is a marker for bone formation.Other markers of bone formation are:Serum osteocalcin• Serum type 1 procollagen (C-terminal/N-terminal)Markers for bone resorption are:Urinary hydroxyprolineUrinary total pyridinoline (PYD)Urinary free deoxypyridinoline (DPD)Urinary collagen type 1 cross-linked N-Telopeptide (NTX)Urinary or serum collagen type 1 cross-linked C-Telopeptide (CTX)Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5bInternational Osteoporosis Foundation has proposed serum CTX and serum PINP (Procollagen 1N-terminal peptide) to be used as reference markers of bone resorption and formation,respectively, for the assessment of fracture risk and monitoring therapy in clinical settings.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.explanation: Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland, which causes primaryhyperparathyroidism (not secondary).Secondary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by high levels of parathyroid hormone, tocompensate for the low levels of serum calcium, due to some other underlying condition.Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism, include:• Chronic kidney disease: The damaged kidneys are unable to produce sufficient amounts of theactive form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. This further causes hypocalcemia andtriggers PTH secretion.•Vitamin D deficiency: Causes hypocalcemia, which triggers the increased secretion of PTH.• Lithium: May cause an increased set-point of calcium for parathyroid hormone suppression,which leads to parathyroid hyperplasia.763
